of Molecular Catalysis, 66 (1991) 329-341 329 Pt/carbon catalysts: effect of pretreatment on the dispersion and morphology of the Pt particles, on their capacity to chernisorb H2 and on the H2/n-C4Hlo reaction Carlos Moreno-Castilla*, Andres Porcel-Jimenez, Francisco Carrasco-Marin and Encarnacion Utrera-Hidalgo DepartanQ. Inorgdnica, F. Ciencias, Universidad de Granada, 18071 Granada (Spain) (Received April 9, 1990; revised January 13, 1991) AbStract Pt/carbon catalysts were prepared from [Pt(NH3)4]C12 as precursor salt and activated carbons as supports. Catalysts were treated at 673 or 773 K in different atmospheres, including He, vacuum, Hz or alternate He-HZ and air-He-H2. The effect of these treatments on the dispersion and morphology of the metallic phase, as well as on the coordination number of the surface Pt atoms, has been studied using HZ chemisorption and transmission electron microscopy. Finally, some of the above catalysts were tested in the hydrogenolysis and isomerization of n-butane, revealing that in the range of particle size studied here, d, the activity for the isomerization did not depend on d; however the activity for hydrogenolysis decreased on decreasing d. On the other hand, the loss of low-coordination surface Pt atoms increased the amount of methane produced. Introduction The properties and morphology of supported small platinum particles depend on a series of factors such as: method of preparation, the kind of support and precursor salt used, as well as the pretreatments given to the catalysts to obtain the metal in its zero-valent state. Thus, it has been found [ 1 ] that in Pt/carbon catalysts prepared from chloroplatinic acid, the dispersion and sintering of the metal particles could be correlated with the porosity of the support, and when tetraammmine platinum(II) chloride was used as precursor salt, the dispersion was greatly affected by the atmosphere of treatment. This last behaviour has previously been reported for Pt/zeolite catalysts [ 2 ] . Moreover, Baker et al. [3] have studied the effect of the support on the behaviour of platinum particles in HZ atmosphere at temperatures between 425 and 1075 K. Their results show that the sintering mechanism depends on the type of interaction between the metal particles and the support; thus for weak interactions such as those in Pt/carbon systems, sintering occurs *Author to whom correspondence should be addressed. 0304-5102/91/$3.50 Elsevier Sequoia/Printed in The Netherlands 330 by particle migration. Arai et al. (4) have also found that in Pt/carbon catalysts the movement of metal particles was affected by the temperature and metal crystallite size. Those with a size greater than 10 nm exhibited a quasi-liquid behaviour. Recently, Wu and Phillips [5] found that Pt particles supported on graphite were preferentially oriented with their (1,1,1) crystallographic planes parallel to the basal planes of graphite after heat treatments in vacuum or oxygen, increasing their degree of alignment with the time and temperature of treatment, as well as dependent on the atmosphere in which it was carried out. This behaviour was again explained [5] in relation to the very weak interactions between the Pt particles and the carbon support. Under these conditions the Pt particles will have their normal equilibrium shape with their surfaces essentially constituted by (1,1,1) planes [6, 7]. This preferential growth of a particular crystalline plane may affect the behaviour of the catalyst, both in the chemisorption of different gases or in a given reaction. It is well known [8-12] that hydrogen can be both weakly and strongly chemisorbed on Pt crystallites. It is expected that hydrogen would be strongly chemisorbed on Pt atoms placed on steps, corners or on crystallographic planes of low coordination such as the (1,0,0) plane, and that it would be weakly chemisorbed on crystallographic planes of high coordination such as the (1,1,1) face. Therefore, the amount of hydrogen weakly chemisorbed would increase with the particle size and/or the preferential growth of a high coordination plane on the surface of the metallic crystallites. On the other hand, Somorjai has found [ 13 ] that in the case of unsupported Pt monocrystals, the (1,0,0) planes had the higher activity and selectivity for n-butane isomerization, and although the (1,0,0) and (1,1,1) planes had the same activity for the hydrogenolysis of the above hydrocarbon, however the product distribution obtained on both planes was quite different. The aim of the present paper is to examine the effect of Pt/carbon catalyst pretreatments on their ability to chemisorb hydrogen, the morphology of the metal particles, and on the hydrogenolysis and isomerization of nbutane. Experimental The supports used in this work were two activated carbons obtained from almond shells (samples A and B). The raw material was activated in COZ flow at 1113 K for different periods of time following the method described elsewhere [ 1 ]. Once the activated carbons were obtained, they were ground and sieved to a particle size between 0.8 and 1.4 mm. Ash content of the samples was between 0.10 and 0.13g'o and they contained no sulphur. Supports were characterized by NZ and COZ adsorption at 77 and 298 K respectively, applying the BET method to the NZ isotherm and the DR method to CO2. Samples were further characterized by He and Hg density 331 TABLE 1 Characteristics of the supports Support S(NZ) S(COZ) VT (m2 g-') (m2 g-') (cm3 g-') A 650 1036 0.560 B 854 1263 0.709 8VT=Total open pore volume. in order to determine their total open pore volume, VT. All these data. are summarized in Table 1. Supported catalysts were prepared from [Pt(NH3)4]C12 (supplied by Alfa Ventron, reagent grade) dissolved in water. A solution of the salt was mixed with the appropriate amount of support and the solvent evaporated at 333 K. The catalysts were then dried at 383 K for 16 h and kept in a desiccator until use. Metal loading was - 1ss'o; the exact amount of Pt was determined after burning off the support at 873 K in air flow in a Mettler TA 3000 thermobalance. In order to decompose the precursor salt and obtain metallic Pt, the supported catalysts were treated either at 673 or 773 K for 2 or 12 h and in different atmospheres such as: He or HZ flow, alternate He and HZ or air-He-HZ flows, and vacuum (10-ss torr). The samples were then evacuated (10-s torr) at the treatment temperature for 1 h and cooled to 298x, and at this temperature they were characterized by HZ chemisorption. Two chemisorption isotherms were obtained between 50 and 250 torr. After completing the first one, the catalyst was outgassed (10-a torr) at 298 K for 1 h (this time was arbitrarily chosen). The method proposed by Benson and Boudart [14] and Wilson and Hall [15] has been followed to determine the HZ uptake in both isotherms. The HZ uptake obtained in the first isotherm, QT, will give the total amount of HZ chemisorbed, and it was assumed that the uptake obtained in the second isotherm will represent the HZ more weakly chemisorbed on the surface metal atoms. This quantity, QR will be referred in the text as a percentage of the total amount of HZ uptake, QT. Blank HZ chemisorption runs were carried out on the supports alone, and did not exhibit any HZ uptake. Dispersion, D, and average crystallite size, d, of the catalysts were obtained from QT values, assuming that one H atom is chemisorbed by one surface Pt atom and that d(nm) -1.08/D [ 1 ]. After the chemisorption experiments, some selected samples were further characterized by transmission electron microscopy (TEM), using a Zeiss EM10C microscope at a magnification between 40 000 x and 200 000 x . Samples were ground and ultrasonically dispersed in toluene. Micrographs were analyzed by an lbas 2000 Kontron image processor, the number of particles counted being not less than 1500; by this procedure, the equivalent- 332 circle diameter of the Pt particles was obtained as a length number or arithmetic mean [16). The n-butane/H2 reaction was studied in a glass plug-flow microreactor; - 1 g of catalyst was introduced into the reactor, the reactant gases flowing upwards through it. The reaction was carried out at 583 K. Catalysts were pretreated in He flow at 673 or 773 K for 2 or 12 h, or in H2 flow at 673 K for 2 h. During the reaction the H2/n-C4Hlo ratio was kept constant at 10/1. The gases were analyzed by gas chromatography using Chromosorb 102 columns and a FID. The experimental procedure followed has been detailed previously [ 17, 18 ). The activity for both hydrogenolysis (rH) and isomerization (r,) was calculated from the expression rX=44.61 PXF(n-C4H,o) W where rx is rI or rH in jmol g cat-' s-', PX is the proportion of n-butane converted to isobutane (PI) or the proportion undergoing hydrogenolysis (PH), F(n-C4-H,o) is the flow rate of n-butane (cm3 min-1) through the reactor and W is the weight of catalyst (g). Results and discussion Helium treatment Catalysts were treated in He flow at 673 or 773 K for 2 or 12 h. It has been reported [ 19) that the precursor salt, during a similar treatment, decomposes according to the following steps: [Pt(NH3)4)CI2-', [pt(NH3)2CI21+2NH3 (1) 3 [ Pt(NH3)2CI2) - 3Pt + N2 + 4NH3 + 6HC1 (2) Reaction (1) takes place between 548 and 588 K and reaction (2) between 588 and 643 K, the Pt(II) being reduced by the NH3 produced in the second step. We assume that, in our case, there will be very weak interactions between the precursor salt and the supports, as has been found for similar Pt/carbon systems, and therefore after the treatment of the catalysts at 673 or 773 K in He platinum will be in its zero-valent state. Hydrogen treatment Hydrogen treatment was carried out at 673 K for 2 h. Results of HZ chemisorption at 298 K are given in Table 4. It is seen that after this treatment the catalysts exhibit a very low dispersion and a high d value. These results can be explained by the mechanism proposed by Dalla Betta and Boudart [2]. They found in Pt/zeolite catalysts, prepared from the same precursor salt, that treatment in HZ produced an intermediate hydride, Pt(NH3)ZH2, which was unstable and mobile, leading to an agglomeration of the particles and therefore to a low dispersion of the Pt particles. This behaviour has also been found previously in Pt/carbon systems [ 1 ]. A typical transmission electron micrograph is shown in Mg. 4. Large agglomerates of particles are observed, clearly indicating that during the treatment the metal particles had a certain mobility on the surface of the supports and grew by coalescence, which causes a very broad particle size distribution as shown .in Fig. 5. Air-helium-hydrogen treatment This treatment was carried out at 673 K, using flowing air for 1 h, He for 15 min and finally HZ for another hour. It has been found [21] for Pt/ Si02 catalysts that a very high dispersion might be obtained if the catalysts were treated in oxygen at 823 K and then reduced in hydrogen. These results were explained in that during the oxygen treatment oxidation of the metal occurred, leading to a rupture of the particles due to the tensions created in them. A later reduction led to a catalyst with a high dispersion. The supports used in this work were not gasified at 673 K in air, however the catalysts A-l.00O Pt and B-0.969'o Pt exhibited a weight loss after the treatment of 7 and 199'o respectively, indicating that Pt was acting as catalyst for the support gasification. The weight loss of catalyst B-0.96sssso Pt was higher because the support B was more activated than A (higher surface area and porosity). Results of HZ chemisorption at 298 K are given in Table 5, which shows that both catalysts present a very low dispersion. This is due to the fact that during treatment the supports were gasified and C02 evolved, which would cause the metal particles to move more rapidly on the surface of the supports than in a similar treatment in vacuum or He [22]. It is interesting to compare the catalyst A-1.00% Pt after HZ and air-He-HZ treatments. Although both treatments lead to similar dispersions, the shape of the Pt particles is quite different, as can be seen in Figs. 4 and 6. Whereas HZ treatment produces irregular particles, the air-He-H2 treatment produces very regular rounded ones, which is attributed to the higher mobility of the particles during this last treatment. In the case of the catalysts treated in He, it is seen that r, is much lower than rH, so these are essentially hydrogenolysis catalysts. The relationship between both reactivities and d is depicted in Fig. 7, which shows that in the range of particle size studied here, ri does not depend on al; however rH increased when the mean particle size decreased. Similar results have been found previously with Pt/A1203 [23, 24] and with Pt/carbon catalysts prepared from chloroplatinic acid [18]. 340 Hydrogenolysis of n-butane can essentially take place by either a- or ss-C-C bond scission and the reaction products can again undergo hydrogenolysis. In the case of Pt/carbon catalysts prepared from chloroplatinic acid [18], it was found that SE values varied between 0.2 and 0.3, indicating cleavage of a-C-C bonds. Furthermore, they did not produce multiple rupture (yield in the same conditions is ~ 30% CHO. However, SE for the present catalysts treated in He varies between 0.07 and 0.16, i.e. they have a much higher tendency to cause a-C-C bond scission and furthermore, they produce multiple cleavage, since the amounts of ethane and propane are lower than that of methane. These results suggest that the hydrogenolysis reaction essentially occurs through the formation of either a -rr-allyl intermediate complex, or an intermediate with multiple carbon-Pt bonds [ 18 ] which would be favored on the smaller metal particles, because of their higher electronic density [23, 25], to give such an intermediate complex. Table 6 shows that when He treatment was carried out at 773 K instead of 673 K the amount of methane produced increases, and it is interesting to note that the B-0.96% Pt catalyst treated at 773 K for 12 h produces a larger amount of methane than that treated for 2 h, although both treatments yielded a catalyst with the same particle size (see Table 2). However, they had different QR values. Results clearly show that an increase in QR value of the catalysts increases the amount of methane produced. The increase in QR was explained earlier as due to a loss of low coordination surface Pt atoms and/or a larger development on the surface of metal particles with high coordination (1,1,1) crystallographic planes. These results agree with those reported by Somorjai [13], who found that the (1,1,1) planes of Pt crystals have a high selectivity for the cleavage of terminal C-C bonds, producing a large amount of methane. Finally, the catalysts treated in HZ have rI values similar to those found when the treatment was in He, and rH values are much lower due to their larger particle size. It is interesting to note the low SE value, which indicates that these catalysts mainly produce multiple hydrogenolysis, yielding very high amounts of methane, very small amounts of ethane and no propane. These results can be attributed to both the high QR and d values that present these catalysts. In conclusion, this work shows that the atmosphere, temperature and time of the treatment given to Pt /carbon catalysts prepared from tetraammine platinum(II) chloride affects the metal particle size and its morphology, as well as the coordination number of the surface metal atoms, which influence the H2 chemisorption at 298 K and the hydrogenolysis and isomerization of n-butane at 583 K. Pt/carbon catalysts were prepared from [Pt(NH3)4]Cl2 as precursor salt and activated carbons as supports. Catalysts were treated at 673 or 773 K in different atmospheres, including He, vacuum, H2 or alternate HeH2 and air-HeH2. The effect of these treatments on the dispersion and morphology of the metallic phase, as well as on the coordination number of the surface Pt atoms, has been studied using H2 chemisorption and transmission electron microscopy. Finally, some of the above catalysts were tested in the hydrogenolysis and isomerization of n-butane, revealing that in the range of particle size studied here, d , the activity for the isomerization did not depend on d ; however the activity for hydrogenolysis decreased on decreasing d .
